You are thinking about an anime which hasncharacters. The characters are labeled from1ton. Every pair of two characters can either mutually love each other or mutually hate each other (there is no neutral state).You hate love triangles (A-B are in love and B-C are in love, but A-C hate each other), and you also hate it when nobody is in love. So, considering any three characters, you will be happy if exactly one pair is in love (A and B love each other, and C hates both A and B), or if all three pairs are in love (A loves B, B loves C, C loves A).You are given a list ofmknown relationships in the anime. You know for sure that certain pairs love each other, and certain pairs hate each other. You're wondering how many ways you can fill in the remaining relationships so you are happy with every triangle. Two ways are considered different if two characters are in love in one way but hate each other in the other. Print this count modulo1 000 000 007.InputThe first line of input will contain two integersn,m(3 ≤n≤ 100 000,0 ≤m≤ 100 000).The nextmlines will contain the description of the known relationships. Thei-th line will contain three integersai,bi,ci. Ifciis 1, thenaiandbiare in love, otherwise, they hate each other (1 ≤ai,bi≤n,ai≠bi,).Each pair of people will be described no more than once.OutputPrint a single integer equal to the number of ways to fill in the remaining pairs so that you are happy with every triangle modulo1 000 000 007.ExamplesInput3 0Output4Input4 41 2 12 3 13 4 04 1 0Output1Input4 41 2 12 3 13 4 04 1 1Output0NoteIn the first sample, the four ways are to:Make everyone love each otherMake 1 and 2 love each other, and 3 hate 1 and 2 (symmetrically, we get 3 ways from this).In the second sample, the only possible solution is to make 1 and 3 love each other and 2 and 4 hate each other.

processed.result:
You are given a set of $n$ people. You know of $m$ relationships between them: some pairs love each other, and some pairs hate each other.  

You want to figure out how many ways you can determine the remaining relationships between the people so that:

*  Every group of three people has either:
    * One pair of people who love each other, and the third person hates both of them.
    * All three people love each other.

Print the number of ways to do this, modulo $10^9 + 7$.

You have a group of people. Some pairs of people are known to either love each other or hate each other.  You need to figure out how many ways you can determine the relationships between the rest of the people so that every group of three people either has exactly one loving pair and one person who hates both, or has all three people loving each other.  The answer should be the number of ways to do this, counting different arrangements as distinct.
